content.p: Data were collected from a survey given to graduating college seniors on the number of times they had changed majors. From that data, a probability distribution was constructed. The random variable X is defined as the number of times a graduating senior changed majors. It is shown below:

body.p: What is the probability that a randomly selected student changed his or her major at least once?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You've found P(changed majors more than twice) or P(changed majors three or more times) Please try again.
Incorrect. You've found P(changed majors more than once). We want P(changed majors at least once). Please try again.
Incorrect. You've found P(changed majors exactly once). We want P(changed majors at least once). Please try again.
Incorrect. You've found P(changed majors at most once). Recall that at least means that number or more. Please try again.

Correct. At least once means one or more times. So P(changed majors at least once) = P(X ≥ 1) = P(X = 1) + P(X = 2) + P(X = 3) + P(X = 4) + P(X = 5). This is .37 + .23 + .09 + .02 + .01 = .72. It is a little easier using complements. P(changed majors at least once) = 1 - P(X = 0). This is 1 - .28, which also is .72.

body.p: What is the probability that a randomly selected student changed his or her major at most twice?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You've found P(X > 2). We want P(X is at most 2). Please try again.
Incorrect. You've found P(X = 2). We want P(X is at most 2). Please try again.
Incorrect. You've found P(X ≥ 2) which means at least 2. We want P(X is at most 2) Please try again.

Correct. We want P(changed majors at most twice). At most means that number or less. P(X ≤ 2) = P(X = 0) + P(X = 1) + P(X = 2) = .28 + .37 + .23 = .88. We also could have used complements. The complement of at most 2 is more than 2. So, P(X ≤ 2) = 1 - P(X > 2). P(X ≤ 2) = 1 - P(X > 2) = 1 - [ P(X = 3) + P(X = 4) + P(X = 5) ]. The only advantage to using this method is that the numbers (.09 + .02 + .01) are easier to add.

body.p: Given that a randomly selected person did change majors, what is the probability that he or she changed majors more than three times?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You've found P(X > 3). However, it is given that the person changed majors, so we are given that X ≥ 1. We want P(X > 3 | X ≥ 1). Please try again.
Good job! We want P(X > 3 | X ≥ 1) = .03 / .72 = .04.
